events.event_description: Renewable energy sources accounted for 22% of U.S. electric power generation, producing 874 billion kWh out of total 4,017 billion kWh.
events.citation: In 2023, the U.S. electric power sector produced 4,017 billion kilowatthours (kWh) of electric power. Renewable sources—wind, solar, hydro, biomass, and geothermal—accounted for 22% of generation, or 874 billion kWh, last year.

events.event_description: Renewable power generation surpassed nuclear generation for the first time in U.S. history.
events.citation: Annual renewable power generation surpassed nuclear generation for the first time in 2021

events.event_description: Renewable power generation exceeded coal generation for the first time in U.S. history.
events.citation: Annual renewable power generation surpassed nuclear generation for the first time in 2021 and coal generation for the first time in 2022.

events.event_description: U.S. solar capacity in the electric power sector reached 95 gigawatts.
events.citation: Planned solar projects increase solar capacity operated by the electric power sector 38% from 95 gigawatts (GW) at the end of 2023

events.event_description: U.S. wind power capacity reached 149 gigawatts.
events.citation: We expect wind capacity to stay relatively flat at 156 GW by the end of 2024, compared with 149 GW in December 2023.
